title: Placebos for Knee Osteoarthritis: Reaffirmation of “Needle Is Better Than Pill”
abstract: Editorials1 September 2015Placebos for Knee Osteoarthritis: Reaffirmation of "Needle Is Better Than Pill"Weiya Zhang, PhD, Kun Zou, PhD, and Michael Doherty, MA, MDWeiya Zhang, PhDFrom School of Medicine, University of Nottingham, Nottingham, United Kingdom., Kun Zou, PhDFrom School of Medicine, University of Nottingham, Nottingham, United Kingdom., and Michael Doherty, MA, MDFrom School of Medicine, University of Nottingham, Nottingham, United Kingdom.Author, Article, and Disclosure Informationhttps://doi.org/10.7326/M15-1580 SectionsAboutFull TextPDF ToolsAdd to favoritesDownload CitationsTrack CitationsPermissions ShareFacebookTwitterLinkedInRedditEmail Many studies and randomized, controlled trials (RCTs) have confirmed that, for many conditions, placebo treatment is more effective than no treatment. Patient expectancy is a key determinant of the placebo effect, and this is influenced by a patient's illness perceptions and experience, as well as various contextual factors (including the patient–practitioner interaction, the environment in which the treatment is received, the branding and color of medications, and whether a treatment is new and expensive or old and cheap) (1). The route of administration also influences expectancy, with greater placebo effects occurring with treatments delivered by needles (injections and acupuncture) or ...References1.
